docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-13 Prosecutors Pursue Bin Laden Web of Terror Federal prosecutors, in a series of little-noticed court filings, have painted the most detailed picture yet of how Osama bin Laden directed what they depict as a worldwide terrorism conspiracy. The government has charged Mr. bin Laden with conspiring to attack Americans, specifically in the embassy bombings in Tanzania and Kenya. 1

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton proposed a $110 billion package of tax credits and subsidies to help people get health insurance over the next decade. He said the plan would cover at least five million uninsured people. He would, for example, let parents enroll in the new Children's Health Insurance Program. And he would help low-wage workers pay premiums for insurance offered by employers. ROBERT PEAR

headline.main: January 16-22; Clinton Offers a Health Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: As insurance fraud cases go, the federal government's case against Dr. Niels H. Lauersen is far from typical. Dr. Lauersen, a well-known Manhattan gynecologist and fertility expert, did not deal with Medicare or Medicaid, the government insurance programs that often attract fraudulent billing schemes. And prosecutors acknowledge that unlike doctors in most medical fraud cases, who bill for procedures that never took place or for patients who do not exist, Dr. Lauersen treated real patients for real conditions, treatments they were desperately seeking.

headline.main: Fraud Case Underscores Debate on Paying for Infertility Care

docs.abstract: Health insurance fraud trial of Dr Nils H Lauersen, well-known Manhattan gynecologist and fertility expert, opens new territory for health fraud cases; Lauersen is accused of billing insurance companies for routine gynecological procedures to cover fertility surgeries for women who could not otherwise get pregnant; law enforcement officials say that over course of 10 years, Lauersen submitted hundreds of false bills amounting to roughly $4 million; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As insurance fraud cases go, the federal government's case against Dr. Niels H. Lauersen is far from typical.    Dr. Lauersen, a well-known Manhattan gynecologist and fertility expert, did not deal with Medicare or Medicaid, the government insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: With growth in the economy and state revenue outstripping nearly every projection, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will propose a budget for 2001 that amounts to an across-the-board loosening of the state's fiscal belt, including a record $1.1 billion for transportation and other capital programs, $760 million more in relief for taxpayers and aid to schools and towns, and hundreds of millions more for colleges and needy hospitals, her closest advisers said today. Spending would rise 8.9 percent, to $21.2 billion, compared with the governor's 2000 budget, the advisers said. And borrowing, a frequent target for Mrs. Whitman's critics, would continue to grow. But even if the New Jersey economy begins to cool slightly, the state's receipts would rise fast enough to provide another huge surplus at year's end, they said: $850 million, or about 4 percent of expenditures.
docs.abstract: Gov Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey will propose budget for 2001 that amounts to across-the-board loosening of state's fiscal belt, including record $1.1 billion for transportation and other capital programs, $760 million for relief for taxpayers and aid to schools and towns, and hundreds of millions more for colleges and needy hospitals; spending will rise 8.9 percent, to $21.2 billion, compared with Whitman's 2000 budget (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBERTA HIPPS, an experienced registered nurse, gave up a secure career as a hospital staff director several years ago for a position that pays about half her former salary, has no job security and requires her to spend several nights a week away from her family. Some people might call her foolhardy. Mrs. Hipps, 56, prefers to think of herself as a servant of the public -- or, rather, of Jacksonville, Fla., where she has sat on the 19-member city council since July 1995.

headline.main: A Run for Office Can Mean a Run on Your Money

docs.abstract: Financial sacrifices person must make in running for one of estimated 513,000 local, state and federal offices discussed; in any given year, between 100,000 and 150,000 seats are up for grabs; Ron Faucheux, editor of Campaigns and Elections magazine, says those planning to run for office can expect to spend between $15,000 and $200,000 to conduct successful citywide campaign in mid- to large-size city and between $25,000 and $300,000 for state legislative office; profile of Alberta Hipps, who left secure career as hospital staff director, to become become member of Jacksonville, Fla, city council; her photo (M)
docs.snippet: ALBERTA HIPPS, an experienced registered nurse, gave up a secure career as a hospital staff director several years ago for a position that pays about half her former salary, has no job security and requires her to spend several nights a week away...

docs.lead_paragraph: On a snowy winter day in 1964, a young man named Peter Cangiliosi was hit by a car on Humboldt Street in Greenpoint, receiving less than serious injuries. He waited more than two hours for a city ambulance to arrive and take him 15 blocks to the Greenpoint Hospital, now closed. Some outraged residents formed the Greenpoint Volunteer Ambulance Corps. Its first rescue vehicle was a 1949 Cadillac hearse, donated by a funeral director. A mutt, Beauty, was adopted as mascot. Robert A. Germino, a founder and nine-time president, says it was the first volunteer ambulance corps in Brooklyn.

headline.main: Ambulance Corps, Just 36, Breathes Its Last

docs.abstract: Article on Greenpoint Volunteer Ambulance Corps, which was formed in 1964 by Robert A Germino and is closing as result of rising costs and dwindling number of volunteers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the year's elections foremost on their minds, Republicans and Democrats return to Capitol Hill on Monday ready to announce a set of crowd-pleasing initiatives, few of which Congress is likely to pass. The proposals are mainly designed to tantalize voters and to serve as partisan weapons the two parties can aim at each other.

headline.main: With Elections in Mind, Congress Plans Agenda

docs.abstract: Republican and Democratic lawmakers will return to Congress after recess to struggle with election-year agendas; are ready to announce initiatives designed mainly to tantalize voters and serve as partisan weapons, but few of which are likely to win Congressional approval; legislative agendas of both parties discussed; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shortly before the bloody military coup of 1973, Ricardo Lagos was appointed by President Salvador Allende Gossens as ambassador to Moscow, and now he is poised to become the second Socialist president in Chile's history. In a twist of post-cold-war ideology and politics, Mr. Lagos, 61, comes to power expressing support for business and promising to govern as a Western European-style Socialist in the mold of former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain.

headline.main: A Mellowed Socialist For Free-Market Chile

docs.abstract: Profile of Ricardo Lagos, who is poised to become second Socialist president in Chile's history; in twist of post-cold-war ideology and politics, Lagos comes to power expressing support for business and promising to govern as Western-style Socialist in mold of former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain; while Lagos's party has Marxist roots, he has been leader of its moderate wing; Lagos can be expected to increase spending on education and health to fulfill his campaign slogan of 'growth with equality'; perhaps, most surprising, he and his aides have promoted plans to quicken pace of privatizations started by two previous Christian Democratic presidents; photo; graph on Chile's economy (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Smuggling Case Reveals Corruption in China A conspiracy that apparently involved Communist Party, police and banking officials smuggled billions of dollars in cars, oil and industrial materials through the southeastern port of Xiamen in the 1990's, evading huge sums in taxes, according to officials familiar with the case. A1 Coup in Ecuador President Jamil Mahuad was replaced by a three-member junta after a rebellion by Indians that was backed by the armed forces. A1
